subject: Re: [junit] Junit Design Patterns.
msgSnippet: ... For TestCases or TestSuites? if TestCases: why?  why not let them be collected automatically? if TestSuites: use New- TestSuite in Eclipse.  You can even
messageBody:
On Sun, 2002-10-13 at 13:33, Levi Cook wrote:
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Dave Astels" <dave@...>
> To: "junit list" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> Sent: Sunday, October 13, 2002 12:56 AM
> Subject: Re: [junit] Junit Design Patterns.
>
>
> > > The "Type-Hierarchy" view in Eclipse (&WSAD) can also be very useful to
> get
> > > a quick idea of what relationships exist.
> >
> > But that only shows inheritance & implementation hierarchies, which
> > should be fairly small anyway. Very little information compared to a
> > good class diagram.
>
> Agreed :)
>
> As it relates to JUnit; A view of my projects I find interesting is to open
> the type-heirarchy with TestCase at the top.
>
> Now that I think of it; it could jump from interesting to downright useful
> if it could export that list somehow... I'm still in a world of manually
> maintained suite methods...

For TestCases or TestSuites?

if TestCases: why? why not let them be collected automatically?
if TestSuites: use New->TestSuite in Eclipse. You can even select a
TestSuite & use New->TestSuite to update it (gives a checkable list of
accessible Tests to include in the generated suite method).

> Levi
>
> PS; A co-worker (meaning I don't really know firsthand..) mentioned that
> Argo can run as an eclipse plug-in too...

Together has a plugin in beta. Apparently it will do much more than
diagramming (metrics, audits, etc. so I hear). I don't expect it will
be free though :(

Dave
--
Dave Astels (dave@...)
Coauthor of "A Practical Guide to XP"
Editor of the Test-Driven Development Edition of The Coad Letter
